SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Richard Henry Luyckx
Present Address: Morden
Pioneer Address: Lac Vaudreuil
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the Questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? about two

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 50%

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? once a week

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? both

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? mostly without an invitation

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? evenings

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? seldom

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? take whatever we have

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? generally the whole family

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? the first buildings (log) were all put up by "bees"

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

for the first few years there would be a bee everyday for two weeks somewhere, would be as much as ten miles and have 20-25 men, the ladies would serve dinner while we would stand around in the snow or be seated on a log.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe, not until our school was built in 1909, until then the dances would be in a house our parties was mostly by way of our literary society which would put on an evening of entertainment, such as debates etc., every two weeks.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. NO

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

The literary meetings were held every two weeks and the men with horses would take turns gathering at the homes and go to where the meeting would be for that time.
MEMORIAL VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first five years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting? How many of these were bachelor's houses? 60%

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once a week

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Not at all

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Mostly unwritten invitation

That time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Evening

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Welcome

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Nada whatever

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "meets" when groups of neighbors came together for a building and quilting, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling where they were held, and how often they occurred.

In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst driving or dancing in homes? Unanswerable

7. In the early years, would the dances mostly be held at our church, or would they be held on an evening of celebration, such as a birthday?

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates...no

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? The Wilburys met up every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc., and knew when the meeting would be for that time.
2. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Describe in the school Questionnaire.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe. All of it, as there was no villages or railroad.

9. When was your first community hall built? (The school was used as such.)

What material was it made of? Lumber

How large was it? About 20' x 50'

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? By the community, funds raised by entertainments, etc.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? In the village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

The new school was built in the village in 1928 and the basement was used as a hall for all functions until its help was put up in 1948.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Only on the nights of the Xmas tree where offered and were prepared.

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? In the school barn until the new school was built and they were put into the living room.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Euchre, whist.

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular? Square dances and waltzes

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Not in the early years, some in later years.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

As a general thing cards was not frowned on only by a very small faction, as we never played for prizes only at a wheat drive, and then the party was put on by the curling club or Agricultural Society and a small prize given.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc.)

If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire, give dates.

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? Who built it - the community organization, etc.? How large was it? How was it used?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? For what purpose did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for all district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? The new school was built in its village in 1928 and the farmyard was used as a hall for all functions until at least 1935.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 9), how many attended? How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Has there ever been playing for prizes? What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home or for community gatherings? Explain.

As a general thing, cards was not known (or only rarely) as we never played for prizes. It was a very casual function, as we never played for prizes only at a what time, and then the story was lost.

OFFICE OF THE SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES
UNIVERSITY OF SASKATCHEWAN

Enclosed are three Archives questionnaires on pioneer schools, churches and recreation. During the past two years the Saskatchewan Archives Board has carried out a policy of distributing questionnaires to old-timers of the province, in order that experiences and events of pioneer life may be recorded and preserved, and we hope that you will assist in this enterprise.

These three questionnaires, No. 3 on pioneer schools, No. 4 on pioneer churches, and No. 5 dealing with recreation and social life, have been sent out as a group, since these are phases of pioneer life in which there was a distinct overlapping of activity. Each questionnaire is complete within itself, but by having the three of them to answer at the same time, it was thought that the person answering them would find it easier to avoid repetition from one questionnaire to another.

We realize that the answering of these will take some time, but you may be sure that your effort will be appreciated, and that all questionnaires which are completed and returned to the Archives Office are valued as part of the permanent record of our province, and provide an important source of information on early provincial settlement. If you wish, you may have someone else write your answers for you. If it is hard for you to write in English, it is quite all right to answer the questions in your own language.

Please give below the names and addresses of other pioneer who could answer these questionnaires. (You may send this form in with your completed questionnaires or may send this in now if you wish, and the questionnaires later).

Two other questionnaires which have been distributed within the past two years are still available; No. 1, "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat", and No. 2, "Pioneer Experiences: A General Questionnaire". If you have not completed these, please put a check mark below and they will be sent to you.

Please send me Archives Questionnaires No.1 and No. 2.

Send to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Your name Henry Lovas
Address (Manitou Wascana)
Box 274
Province of Saskatchewan

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

Out of habit, each family had lunch, everyone sat down for dinner, all helped themselves, everything was free except the beer and the booth, the profits went for prizes for games.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Tea - water, beer, no prizes for games.

33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Playing football when there was water or puddles all over the grounds. If you fell down, we would have to carry the water out from under a woman spectator who hit us in the head with her hat pin. The game was held for an hour until a new ball was obtained.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Each community had its own organization that they own picnic, but would have visiting teams from one community to another, and each community would visit the other at their respective picnics and Christmas entertainments.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

From 1918 on, when cars became numerous and people wanted to go to the larger centers, the greater change took place after 1923 when the R.R. went through. We were 30 miles from any town or by way of that time.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Everyone almost was always willing to help. Men and women of 60 would run races.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1906

How long did it continue? Until about 1925

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

Until 1920 there was competition between these different settlements, each having the same organization and competed at each of their respective picnics, for sport only. No prizes were given.

About 1928 used for hockey. A curling rink was built about the same time.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

The basement of the curling rink was used still used for serving tea, etc., at W.A. and country club meetings not as often now as a few years ago.
